title: 109_s765
content: The Act may be cited as the "Math and Science Incentive Act of 2005". Congress finds that the United States needs a robust scientific and technical enterprise, requiring more scientists and engineers. The education system must encourage students to study science and mathematics, as current performance lags behind international peers. The US must recommit to investing in research, development, and education. The United States must recommit to leadership in science, mathematics, and engineering to maintain technological advancement. Loan forgiveness programs can attract students to careers in these fields, including teaching. Establishment of program for loan forgiveness to attract students to careers in science, mathematics, and engineering, including teaching. The Secretary will implement a program to cover interest payments on loans for undergraduate students who meet specific criteria outlined in the Act. Undergraduate students meeting specific criteria outlined in the Act, including being new borrowers, teachers of STEM subjects, or STEM professionals, can have their interest payments covered by the Secretary for loans. The Secretary will not cover interest that accrues before the repayment period begins. The Secretary will not make interest payments that accrue before the repayment period begins on certain loans. Participants for the program will be selected based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs. The Secretary will select program participants based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs, as well as academic record or job performance. Eligible applicants may also be chosen based on their likelihood of success. The Secretary selects program participants based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs, academic record, and job performance. Eligible applicants may be chosen based on their likelihood of completing the service obligation, staying in science, mathematics, or engineering, or other relevant criteria determined by the Secretary. Loan interest payments are subject to appropriations. Loan interest payments under this Act are subject to appropriations, with priority given to individuals who received payments in the previous fiscal year. The Secretary is authorized to create regulations for this section. The period for interest payments begins on the agreement's effective date, continues after fulfilling the service obligation, and ends upon completion. The Secretary pays interest on behalf of student borrowers selected under subsection (a) starting from the agreement's effective date until the completion of the repayment period, payment of $10,000, cessation of service obligation fulfillment, or 6 months after the borrower's income exceeds 4 times the national per capita income. The Secretary pays interest on behalf of student borrowers selected under subsection (a) until repayment completion, $10,000 payment, service obligation fulfillment, or 6 months after income exceeds 4 times national per capita income. Repayment to eligible lenders is made by the Secretary according to regulations. Application for repayment is required. The Secretary pays interest on behalf of student borrowers selected under subsection (a) until repayment completion. Eligible individuals must submit an application for loan interest payment, agreeing to repay the Secretary if they fail to complete the required service. If the individual fails to complete the required service, they must repay the Secretary for any interest paid on their behalf. Consolidation loans may qualify for interest payment if used to repay specific types of loans under the Higher Education Act. The borrower must repay loans made under specific sections of the Higher Education Act or Federal Direct Stafford Loans. They cannot receive benefits from this section and certain other loan forgiveness programs for the same service. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "mathematics, science, or engineering professional" is defined as someone with a degree in science, mathematics, or engineering working in a related field, including as a professor at a higher education institution. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years to implement this Act.
